Claims.expr: equation of the resulting line after translating y = 3x + 5 two units to the right
equation of the resulting line after translating y = 3x + (v - 1) two units to the right
N = number of schedules where 6 labeled teams each play exactly 3 distinct opponents
Fix team A; choose set S of 3 opponents for A from 5 others: 10 ways
Without loss of generality, fix S = {B, C, D}, T = {E, F}
Case 1: No edges within S. Add all 6 edges from S to T. Degrees: A=3, each in S=3 (A + 2 in T), each in T=3 (all in S). Valid schedule; 1 way
Case 2: Exactly one edge within S, say {B, C}. B and C each have degree 2 (A and each other); must each connect to one in T, 2! = 2 ways (e.g., B-E & C-F or B-F & C-E)
After adding one edge in S and assignments to T: A, B, C degree 3; D degree 1 (A); each in T degree 1. Add all 3 edges within {D, E, F}: D=3 (A + E + F), each in T=3 (one from {B,C} + D + other in T)
Case 2 per fixed S: 3 choices for edge × 2 assignments = 6 ways
Three edges within S (triangle): A, B, C, D degree 3; E, F degree 0. Only possible edge E-F gives degrees 1 each; cannot reach 3. Impossible
Two edges within S (e.g., B-C, B-D, no C-D): B degree 3; C, D degree 2; E, F degree 0. Assigning C, D to T (without C-D) leads to E, F unable to reach degree 3 after adding E-F. Impossible
No other cases possible beyond Case 1 and Case 2
N = number of schedules where (s_n + 3) labeled teams each play exactly 3 distinct opponents

Math_Problem: If \( x=2 \) and \( v=3x \), what is the value of \((2v-5)-(2x-5)\)? Instead of determining the numerical value of the given algebraic expression, simply find \( k = v - 1 \), where \( v \) is the quantity defined in terms of \( x \) as stated. The line with equation $y = 3x + k$ is translated 2 units to the right. What is the equation of the resulting line? Instead of determining the equation of the translated line, simply find $k = s_n + 3$, where $s_n$ is the slope of the original line. $k$ soccer teams are competing in a tournament in Waterloo. Every team is to play three games, each against a different team. How many different schedules are possible?
